data.text: This year's #ECBForum on Central Banking takes place on 17-19 June. The theme will be 20 years of European Economic and Monetary Union. Here is the programme as it stands https://t.co/wYMvxbWWmj #EUROat20 https://t.co/iY50Ef9yNz

We asked around 150 banks in the euro area about changes in their lending behaviour and loan demand during the first quarter of 2019. Find out the results https://t.co/OBQsNjpxVo https://t.co/6nmgDMsS9P

Bank governance and risk management have worsened, as shown by the 2018 results of the annual Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process – despite the fact that most banks hold more high-quality capital than required. Find out more https://t.co/8vB4NXluqW https://t.co/1Wc2eDjWF7
ECB Banking Supervision publishes results of 2018 Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP) https://t.co/DHseSKGB1Q

Meet Irena, Ben and Mireia. They’re working at the ECB as part of our Graduate Programme! Interested in the 2019 programme? Applications close at midnight on 8 April https://t.co/4PFTTZXG8q https://t.co/J7ta6IF0aG

We have made progress on one of the top priorities for ECB Banking Supervision: the Targeted Review of Internal Models (TRIM). It is clear that banks need to do more to address the deficiencies detected. To find out more, read our letter to banks https://t.co/JbbHzvEZJD https://t.co/nsfCAKsdxA

Less than 10 seconds. As of November 2018, that’s the amount of time people and businesses need to transfer money across Europe. Read our Annual Report to discover more about the launch of the TARGET instant payment settlement (TIPS) https://t.co/pWGN0vQPjt https://t.co/icIhmbOXTI

Inflation in the eurozone increased further in 2018, moving toward our objective of below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. Want to know which sectors drove this inflation? Read our Annual Report to find out https://t.co/kOqB3AwZS8 https://t.co/yutmrVwAg0
Interview Sabine Lautenschläger with Der Standard https://t.co/1ZL5S5iQhR (EN) https://t.co/t8Rhzik04u (DE)

What did the students discover? Which questions were up for debate? We followed the students’ journey over the two days on our Instagram account. Check it out here https://t.co/XbinbF6QvC

200 students from all over Europe simulated a European Council meeting at the ECB on 28 and 29 March. They took on a variety of roles, from interpreters to heads of state, and discussed important European issues, such as the future of the eurozone https://t.co/8AFlPccfVQ https://t.co/lNovcacfpD

Want to present your paper at the next ECB conference on fiscal policy and Economic and Monetary Union governance? We’re looking for papers on a variety of topics – find out more https://t.co/ZJETd30XzG https://t.co/isYj1Ac6LH
Find out more about the latest research on macroprudential policies in our Macroprudential Bulletin https://t.co/Ivc0xezC8E 4/4 https://t.co/Q8Dr8zgIni

Euro area banks are better prepared to look after themselves in the event of losses. The introduction of larger capital buffers, a bail-in framework and the Single Resolution Fund has increased the banking system’s loss-absorbing capacity while minimising costs to taxpayers 3/4 https://t.co/OPRFShd5I2
Euro area banks are more resilient today. The likelihood of them being unable to meet their obligations within a year decreased significantly between 2007 and 2017 2/4 https://t.co/xGozNHScHt

(Thread) Is taxpayers’ money better protected today than before the financial crisis? Yes, shows the latest Macroprudential Bulletin assessing the impact of regulatory reforms since 2007. Read on and check the article to find out why https://t.co/sDfW1jWR7d 1/4
Speech Yves Mersch: Necessity, proportionality and probity – central bank independence in unconventional times https://t.co/N8AhtHtiVA

Our Macroprudential Bulletin examines the loss-absorbing capacities of the banking sector, the resilience of euro area banks, financial stability risks stemming from the real estate markets and countries’ decisions on the countercyclical capital buffer https://t.co/taEKIoiNQF https://t.co/DcycFxWPIq

Executive Board member Sabine Lautenschläger returned to her former school this week to speak with students about Europe. One of the things they talked about was the upcoming European elections. https://t.co/Lfrt5bIYdb
Speech Luis de Guindos: International spillovers of monetary policy and financial stability concerns https://t.co/AaRUv4luw1
Working paper: Taylor-rule consistent estimates of the natural rate of interest https://t.co/1SqBovmlHz
Working paper: Does liquidity regulation impede the liquidity profile of collateral? https://t.co/dO2KauKhKx
Speech Pentti Hakkarainen: Central banking and banking supervision in today’s financial markets https://t.co/aQskO8Vdr9
Speech Sabine Lautenschläger: Cross-border banking since the crisis – lessons for supervisors https://t.co/icNSr5APx9
Speech Peter Praet: Providing monetary policy stimulus after the normalisation of instruments  https://t.co/oiTV32HlJu
Draghi: The ECB will adopt all the monetary policy actions that are necessary and proportionate to achieve its objective. We are not short of instruments to deliver on our mandate. 7/7

Draghi: Our current reaction function is well designed to respond to further delays in inflation convergence. In such a situation, we would ensure that monetary policy continues to accompany the expansion by adjusting our forward guidance to reflect the new inflation outlook. 6/7

Draghi: Our March decisions ensure that our policy stance remains accommodative in the face of a weaker growth outlook. And the calibration of the remaining parameters of the TLTRO III will reflect the evolving macroeconomic conditions. 5/7

Draghi: We remain confident that the sustained convergence of inflation to our aim has been delayed rather than derailed – meaning that we expect inflation to reach our objective at a later date than we previously foresaw. 4/7
Draghi: Our medium-term outlook remains that growth will gradually return to potential, but the risks remain tilted to the downside. 3/7

Draghi: The last year has seen a loss of growth momentum in the euro area, which has extended into 2019. This has been predominantly driven by pervasive uncertainty in the global economy that has spilled over into the external sector. 2/7

(THREAD) Our March decisions ensure that our policy stance remains accommodative in the face of a weaker growth outlook. Read Mario Draghi’s speech on the current state of the euro area economy and what this means for monetary policy https://t.co/QQPz7y1ski 1/7
Speech Mario Draghi: Monetary policy in the euro area https://t.co/QQPz7y1ski

The quality of banks’ assets further improved in 2018. During the first five years of European banking supervision, the non-performing loans ratio fell to 4.2% in 2018 from 8% in 2014. Check out our Annual Report to find out more about NPLs https://t.co/j1rkrDl2LA 3/3 https://t.co/Zj59t9FjWl

Banks’ ratios of the highest quality capital – Common Equity Tier 1 – rose to 14.1% in 2018 from 11.3% at the end of 2014, which is when European banking supervision was launched. Read our Annual Report available in 22 European languages https://t.co/sJTLZUmLUF 2/3 https://t.co/Vch5LYOBI6

Banks supervised by the ECB maintained stable levels of capital and further reduced their bad loans in 2018. Read the ECB Annual Report on supervisory activities and find out more about the ECB’s supervisory work and the state of the banking sector https://t.co/C6d6wunNwA 1/3 https://t.co/Jz1Tl82pAX

Want to know what the next steps for the Working Group on risk-free rates are? Find out here https://t.co/Gsas0YwF55
